author: DetkoEUBA
body:
My comment applies to Europe. 

Coca Cola + Pepsico in the soft drinks segment (Coke+Pepsi, Sprite+7UP, Fanta+Mirinda)

Definitely Microsoft in OS segment with their Windows. Never saw a different OS on the computer (I don't count Macs because their users cannot install their preferred OS). In the past Microsoft used to rule with their MS Office, but Alphabet is competing now with their Google Docs and Sheets. Same applies to web browsers, when IE was the 90%+ browser, they lost it to Alphabet with their Chrome (actually they lost to Mozilla's Firefox before, but no one remembers)

Alphabet in the web search area with their Google and smartphone OS segment with their Android (again I don't include iPhones here for the same reason). 

Mastercard+Visa: I've never seen a different card in my life. 

Boeing+Airbus in commercial flight segment: never seen a different plane in any European airlines I used. 

LinkedIn in the professional social network segment.

author: bush_killed_epstein
body: Depends on the TA. The pairs trading algorithm I’m working on finds 2 stocks that are closely related (my go to example is always Visa and MasterCard) and then estimates how much of MasterCard stock you should buy to perfectly hedge your Visa stock using ordinary least squares linear regression on previous data. You could sort of call that TA, because it is a strategy that only trades based on price data. However, it gives me some pretty decent risk-adjusted returns (Sharpe Ratio)

author: Just-Touch-It
body:
Always been a big fan of Discover from a customer perspective. Great customer service, good rewards, and treated me well in the past. I looked into them about two years and maybe things have changed since then but I couldn’t really find anything that stood out with them and the stock has always sort of dragged behind others on the sector.

Visa and MasterCard are great because they’re so widely used, don’t actually offer credit, and basically run the payment processing sector. Sure, there are smaller players who are making noise but the reach Visa and MasterCard have is incredible. American Express found its niche in great service, attractive rewards, offering no limits, and being viewed as a card for wealthy or sophisticated people or businesses. 

Discover just hasn’t been able to find that niche or special thing that makes them stand out. Unlike Visa or MasterCard, they take on more risk because they actually offer credit to customers which can be a concern if the economy turns for the worse and people start struggling to pay off debt. Discover started making some noise a few years back via their rewards and sign up bonuses but now every credit card and bank offers them and those rewards aren’t cheap for the providers. Who they cater to is important too, American Express caters more towards businesses and wealthy individuals while a company likes Discover caters more towards college students, lower and middle class individuals, and regular Joes which all tend to be hit harder and have more trouble paying back debt during tough times.

Like the other user said, their delinquency rate has increased as of rate and there has also been some concern over raising operating costs. That makes for a nasty combo of the economy takes a turn for the worse, something people have waiting for for what seems like an eternity. 

One thing I will say about Discover is that from a value perspective, they’re probably one of the more reasonably valued companies in the sector. I love and hold Visa but it’s getting a little heated right now valuation wise. I believe MasterCard is in a similar boat. American Express is relatively reasonable. That said, it’s valued the way it is for a reason. Wall Street isn’t confident the growth is there for Discover and basically sees them being stuck where they are with the added of risk of offering credit that Visa and MasterCard don’t have.

I’d personally pass. Not a bad company and I’ve had nothing but good experiences with them but I think you can see better growth elsewhere.

Stock has done well, market wanted a beat and got a quarter that was merely okay. Not surprising, didn't meet expectations. Additionally, while I certainly think Visa is an excellent company, I don't think it has been quite as well managed since Charlie Scharf (who once went after Paypal, "The other door is where we go full steam and compete with them in ways that people have never seen before. Because you've never seen us go target PayPal in the marketplace in any meaningful way.", https://www.vox.com/2016/5/25/11768854/visa-ceo-paypal-threat) left. Scharf was an excellent CEO.

While not massively so, Mastercard especially in the last year or two feels more and more like the more well-run company of the two.

author: draw2discard2
body:
Not advocating for DFS versus V and MA, but the latter to do have INSANE valuations at the moment. I don't remember when I sold my positions in them--I'm sure I missed out on great gains--but when I did so it was because I saw them as already very overvalued, and they have just continued to grow since.

Obviously they are extremely well-positioned at the moment, and there is still GOOD growth in the area there is not the EXPLOSIVE growth that their valuations suggest. There is also a ton of risk in the medium to long term since technologically there is no reason why everyone really needs to go through them for processing payments. Its entirely possible--given that their business is predicated on taking 3 percent of every dollar spent--that more and more merchants and consumers will adapt existing and developing means to bypass that, the immediate effect being that they will have to cut their rake to prolong their period of competitiveness.

author: PM-ME-PICSOFYOURDOG
body:
I don’t know.  It’s in an IRA.  In 2010 I bought 15 shares.  When they doubled I sold 7 and was left with 8.  After a few years I started adding 5+ shares at a time.  I’d sell something else and take a portion of the proceeds and put it in amazon.  My OCD wanted a round number so I stopped in 2018 when I got 50.   I’ve done the same with Apple.    I bought/sold awhile, but stopped that in 2013 and still hold those shares.   Both have more than doubled and have taken zero effort besides “buy a little more periodically.”   Zero stress around timing calls correctly, no second guessing myself when to sell. 

To a lesser degree I’ve done the same with MA NFLX.  All have treated me well  with over 100%!lgains and I’m not tempted to chase gain porn in the short term.

author: bd_one
body:
Me today...

9:00 am: Eh, futures are about even. We'll be fine by open. Payday is today, so I might top off my checking account and squirrel half my check in those Bulletshares Junk Bond ETFs like I planned.

10:00 am: All the major indexes open in the red. Try to average down my position in ROST with half my paycheck since it is down and heading back up quickly.

11:00 am: ROST limit order clears at $117 a share. See that Visa is down even more than ROST. *Real shit*, dunk down another paycheck in fractional shares that closes at the end of the day for Visa, and Mastercard too just because. Trading window at 3:45 pm.

2:00 pm: Forget that SoFi has an instant deposit limit of $1000 per clearing period, so over 1/3 of my deposit isn't available for 4 business days.

3:45 pm: Somehow Mastercard clears at $323.98 per share and Visa at $206.62. No idea how they arrived at that.

Now I'm just waiting 4 business days to see the $258 from the transaction that didn't clear...

author: Zer033x
body:
Two things that work are bollinger bands and moving averages. Watch those and you'll be surprised when you see stocks continuously bounce off of a lower bollinger up to the mid band, or bounce off a 200 day moving average. 

Obviously a stock can dip below a ma or lower bollinger but usually won't without news, or a market correction. Have to also have a sense of the current market. If it's a good bull market but there's a bad day then stocks are likely to all fall to lower bollinger, but will rebound to mid bollinger in coming days, or top bollinger. 

Another way to use it is if a stock starts a move up or down, it usually won't stop until it tests the bollinger it's heading towards. So if a stock has 210 200 190 top mid bottom bollinger, and it starts to rise to 195, it likely won't reverse until at least 200 test.

Disney: They will never go away, let's be real. They own a huge part of American entertainment, acquired a ton of comic franchises, and as long as they continue to produce great movies and add to the world of their franchises, they'll continue to a good buy.

Visa: payment processing, and as long as people continue to use less cash and more credit cards, Visa/Mastercard/AmEx will be good buys.

Microsoft: Until people stop using Windows, I have no reason to say 'sell' for them.

author: epicanthus
body: If you're referring to OP's post, the idea is that Visa and Mastercard aren't banks. They don't give loans. Your credit card is issued by your bank, and you're given a credit account by the bank. Visa/Mastercard are companies that just allow you to make transactions with the card - they don't hold any of the actual loans. They're just a middleman that takes a small cut of the transaction you make between your bank's credit account and the seller's account. That's why OP's saying Visa etc isn't nearly as risky - it's because when shit hits the fan like 2008, they're not screwed because they don't deal in loans that could go default (and did go default back in 2008).

author: DragonStrategy
body:
Honestly, this is the part where I think you should listen to earnings calls from each of them and read some of their investor presentations. We cannot do full DD for you and if you want to understand these better, you have to focus on them yourself. 

My take is that Visa is the strongest company because of its business model, current international support, and involvement in new methods of payment. Amex has the most potential because its international opportunity is not yet tapped and it sounds like China is going to allow Amex to start doing business there on a wider scale. 

I do not like Mastercard. No credit card that I am interested in is branded by Mastercard.

Video game company comparison: V = Sony, AXP = Microsoft, MA = Sega, ?? = Nintendo

author: redtexture
body:
This is an example of the collapse of an futures/options fund advisor, for Natural Gas, in November 2018.   

The event was not particularly caused by natural demand events, but more by predictions, and changes in storage policies industry wide.   

There are many reasons for price moves, and being right about longer term direction does not mean the trader automatically avoids failure. 


OptionSellers.com / James Cordier - Full apology video  
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VNYNMM0hXXY

author: langlois44
body:
Come on man, you still aren't counting any costs or using any facts. 

Okay, I got some time and this is pretty simple, so here's some actual math. I don't think facts will change your mind, but maybe OP or someone else reading this will learn something.

* You state $1400-$1800 in rent revenue. /u/kileek states that this would either be an undesireable condo or small, but I looked up actual condos for sale in Victoria, and found [this one](https://www.point2homes.com/CA/Condo-For-Sale/BC/Victoria/James-Bay/500-Oswego-St/82583898.html) for $300,000, so I'll use this as a comparison. It's pretty nice, but it's a 545 sq ft 1 bed 1 bath. I found several similar apartments, pretty close to that condo, renting for $1175-$1695 ([here](https://www.kijiji.ca/v-apartments-condos/victoria-bc/bachelor-available-at-1039-view-street-victoria/1480133121), [here](https://www.kijiji.ca/v-apartments-condos/victoria-bc/rockland-1-bdrm-2nd-floor-corner/1480132252), [here](https://www.kijiji.ca/v-apartments-condos/victoria-bc/1-bdrm-available-at-976-humboldt-street-victoria/1480133124), [here](https://rentals.ca/victoria?types=condo&beds=1%2B&active-listing-id=293490)). The $1695 one looks nicer to me, so let's use $1600 for rent (halfway in your range so I think that's fair).
* 20% down payment and 30 year amortization, variable rate mortgage (at 2.65%) is actually a $965/month payment. Use the mortgage calculator here:  [https://www.ratehub.ca/mortgage-payment-calculator](https://www.ratehub.ca/mortgage-payment-calculator) 
* That building lists its condo fees as $459/mo.
* Assuming the tax assessment is also $300,000, the property taxes are $1500 a year, or $125/mo. Property tax estimator here:  [https://www.victoria.ca/EN/main/residents/property-taxes/estimator.html](https://www.victoria.ca/EN/main/residents/property-taxes/estimator.html) 
* You probably want some insurance eh? If you google [condo insurance Victoria](https://www.google.com/search?q=insurance+cost+victoria+condos&rlz=1C1GCEA_enCA767CA767&oq=insurance+cost+victoria+condos&aqs=chrome..69i57j33.6547j0j4&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8), the ads suggest it will be $40/mo. 
* Most rules of thumb say to try and save 1% of the value for maintenance, but the condo fees do a lot of the heavy lifting here. Let's say OP needs to save 0.25% for maintenance, that's $62.50 a month. 
* If you looked closely at the $1695/month apartment up there, you'll notice that actually included water and cable costs. Is OP going to pay those? [Water bills are $128/month](https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/in-victoria-less-is-more-when-it-comes-to-paying-for-water/article1215390/), so let's hope not (even though a lot of those Victoria apartments do include water in the rent).

Let's only count those costs okay? Even though there are obviously more costs (and we didn't count lower fees or anything to close the sale).

So we rent it for $1600, and our costs are actually $1651.50, so there is actually negative cash profit for OP. But you're building equity, you'll rightly say. You're right, your mortgage payments are paying roughly $450 of principal every month. So this property actually "profits" $400/month, even though there is no cash for OP. 

What could OP get with just margin? First some facts

* XRE paid $0.81 per unit of distributions in 2019 ([source](https://www.blackrock.com/ca/individual/en/products/239843/ishares-sptsx-capped-reit-index-etf#distributionsDialog)).
* Current market price $19.49.
* [Interactive Brokers' margin rate is 2.25%](https://www.interactivebrokers.ca/en/index.php?f=45266) using OP's $60,000 down payment as an account cash contribution.
* [IB requires you to put up 50% of the value](https://www.interactivebrokers.ca/en/index.php?f=202&p=stk) (so you can only use margin to pay for half).

OP's $60,000 means they can buy $120,000 of XRE. That investment would bring in $4987.17 a year, minus $1350/yr in interest, means OP actually takes home $3337.17 a year in cash, or $278.10 a month (compared to the condo's cash flow of -$51.50). 

As you can see, OP does not make "literally twice as much" with the condo, and he doesn't have a dime of cash flow. Yes, if you are counting the mortgage paydown as profit (which it is), the condo does make a bit more, but it isn't close to twice as much. 

If any of my numbers are wrong, I'd be happy to hear how. None of the numbers you've stated other than rent have even been close.

author: bartturner
body:
Google cloud is growing faster than Microsoft.  But more important with Google is that cloud is just one lever.  They have so many others.

Alphabet/Waymo is doing things with self driving cars nobody else can and looks like nobody else close.   All done without a driver or backup driver.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UX_N2up7f8Q

https://www.instagram.com/p/B5tP5XqlZpb/?igshid=1m8k9m1rv6ksx

https://twitter.com/waymo/status/1194705739492708352?s=21

With AI Google leads in every layer of the AI stack.

But probably the biggest for Google is their lead in every layer of the AI stack. From silicon all the way up to the engineers. Algorithms Google is miles ahead of everyone.

So the lowest layer is Silicon

"Cloud TPU Pods break AI training records"

https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/ai-machine-learning/cloud-tpu-pods-break-ai-training-records

The next layer up is the OS for AI. Which Google completely dominates with TensorFlow with over 140K stars now on GitHub.

https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow

Next up is the algorithms. Here is the canonical place papers are submitted with AI algorithms and year in and year out Google leads in papers accepted.

https://miro.medium.com/max/1235/1*HfhqrjFMYFTCbLcFGwhIbA.png Then there is the data. Which I think everyone knows Google has more than anyone. By far. The most valuable of any data is what you get through search. Google now has 93% share overall and most important 96% on mobile.

Google chief competitor, Microsoft with Bing, lost 50% of their market share on mobile in the last year.

https://gs.statcounter.com/search-engine-market-share/mobile/worldwide

Then the next layer up is engineers with recruiting and retention. Google is the dream place to work for young people. It give Google the top draft choices year in and year out.

"23,000 Millennial and Gen Z workers listed their dream employers and there’s 1 key difference"

https://www.cnbc.com/2018/09/12/23000-millennial-and-gen-z-workers-listed-their-dream-employers.html

Retention Google continues to be rated the best place to work of the big tech companies.

“The World’s Best Employers 2019: Alphabet Takes Top Spot”

https://www.forbes.com/sites/sarahhansen/2019/10/18/the-worlds-best-employers-2019-alphabet-takes-top-spot-followed-by-microsoft-and-red-hat/#6e694cd052ef

“Top Companies 2019: Where the U.S. wants to work now”

Can't share link as this sub will not allow. But do a search on what provided to see Google rated #1.

Google has barely even got started. We are like 1 inning into a 9 inning game. They are currently growing at 20% and really with all their levers they should be able to keep growth 15% or higher for the next decade.

Will be fun to see in 2030 if Alphabet continues to be the company to own for another decade. I suspect that will be true.

BTW, Google is also the most cash rich company on the planet to boot

"Google parent Alphabet overtakes Apple to become world's most cash-rich company"

https://www.cnet.com/news/google-parent-alphabet-overtakes-apple-to-become-worlds-most-cash-rich-company/

But with less than $5B of debt ;)

author: Ellicott12
body: Square is the platform which support Visa’s or Mastercard’s or Amex’s payment processing. You could make the argument that Square’s Cash App (their version of Venmo) could take some of the market share but it’s more likely that it’s expanding addressable market of transactions than cannibalizing the transactions which would usually be routed through Visa/MasterCard

author: nj_redditor_91
body: Not much.  I would say American Express is the closest you will find.  Visa and MasterCard are toll roads who make money off of every transaction.  AmEx is exposed to credit risk while Visa and MasterCard are not.  But since they collect data from both the customer and merchant side they can market more individualized products.  AmEx customers also tend to spend more.

body: I was looking at INTC, JPM, AVGO, VYM, VIG, PG, V, and DIS. I'll probably look more toward JPM, VIG, and PG this year but am still researching.

author: marinegeo
body: V

author: dvdmovie1
body: There's no need for Apple to unseat Mastercard or Visa. The new Apple Card is a Mastercard. If I'm Apple and I can get a tiny piece of every Apple Pay transaction without having to build the rails (which would come at enormous cost) or having to face the regulatory scrutiny that a financial entity like V/MA do, not a bad deal for Apple. None of these tech companies wants to be a financial company and then face regulatory scrutiny like one.
